December 2018 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 19:56, 24 December 2018 (UTC) }} '''Charles Joseph John Hart''' (born 19 April 1987) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] for {{English football updater|Burnley}} club [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] and the [[England national football team|English national team]]. With over 100 Premier League clean sheets, Hart holds the joint record for the most [[Premier League Golden Glove]] awards (four) and has amassed 75 international caps since his debut in 2008.
He began his career at his hometown club [[Shrewsbury Town F.C.|Shrewsbury Town]] in the [[Football Conference]] and [[EFL League Two|League Two]]. In 2006, he moved to top-flight Manchester City, having attracted the attention of several Premier League teams. He spent time on loan at [[Tranmere Rovers F.C.|Tranmere Rovers]] and [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] in his first season, before spending the 2009–10 season at [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]]. Hart was nominated for the [[PFA Young Player of the Year]] and was voted as the [[PFA Team of the Year (2010s)#Premier League|Premier League goalkeeper of the 2009–10 season]] in recognition of his performances at Birmingham. He returned to Manchester City for the 2010–11 season and won the Golden Glove for keeping the most [[clean sheets]] throughout the Premier League season. Hart replicated this feat in the 2011–12 season and was a key player during City's [[2011–12 Premier League|title-winning campaign]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mcfc.co.uk/News/Team-news/2012/May/Hart-QPR-preview |title=Hart wins Golden Glove award for Manchester City – Manchester City FC |publisher=Manchester City F.C. |accessdate=12 May 2014}}</ref> He won the Golden Glove for the third year in a row in the [[2012–13 Premier League|following season]], and earned a second Premier League title in 2014. In 2015, Hart once again won the Golden Glove award for the fourth time in five years.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.premierleague.com/en-gb/news/news/2014-15/may/250515-sergio-aguero-and-joe-hart-seal-golden-awards-double-for-manchester-city.html |title=Aguero and Hart seal Golden Awards double for Man City |publisher=Premier League |date=25 May 2015 |accessdate=26 May 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150526024954/http://www.premierleague.com/en-gb/news/news/2014-15/may/250515-sergio-aguero-and-joe-hart-seal-golden-awards-double-for-manchester-city.html |archivedate=26 May 2015}}</ref> With the arrival of [[Pep Guardiola]] in 2016, Hart was dropped for selection by the new manager and made only one appearance in the Champions League before moving on loan to [[Torino F.C.|Torino]] and [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] in successive seasons. He then signed a permanent transfer to Burnley after having being told he had no first team future with City.
A former regular for England at [[England national under-21 football team|Under-21 level]], Hart made his senior international debut in June 2008, and was recognised as England's first-choice goalkeeper from 2010 to 2017.<ref>{{cite news |title=Manchester City keeper Joe Hart could be England's most capped player ever, says David James |last=Wilson |first=Jeremy |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/england/8511486/Manchester-City-keeper-Joe-Hart-could-be-Englands-most-capped-player-ever-says-David-James.html |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=13 May 2011 |accessdate=13 May 2011}}</ref> He has gained over 70 caps and was selected in England's squads for two [[FIFA World Cup]]s and as many [[UEFA European Championship]]s.
==Early life== Hart was born in [[Shrewsbury]], Shropshire, to Charles Hart, who sold gym equipment, and his wife Louise, a nursery school teacher.<ref name=Telegraphbio>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/manchester-city/9792712/Manchester-City-and-England-in-safe-hands-with-Joe-Hart-between-the-posts.html |title=Manchester City and England in safe hands with Joe Hart between the posts |first=Mark |last=Bailey |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=11 January 2013 |accessdate=22 February 2018}}</ref> He attended Oxon Primary School, followed by [[Meole Brace School]] in Shrewsbury, where he was [[Head Boy]] in his final year.<ref name=guardian>{{cite news |title=Joe Hart 'would love' to play for Manchester City again |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2009/aug/28/joe-hart-birmingham-manchester-city |newspaper=The Guardian |date=29 August 2009 |location=London |first=Daniel |last=Taylor |accessdate=6 May 2010}}</ref> As a schoolboy, he was an equally competent [[cricket]]er and briefly played for [[Shrewsbury Cricket Club|Shrewsbury CC]] in the [[Birmingham and District Premier League]] and also spent two years in [[Worcestershire County Cricket Club|Worcestershire]]'s youth squads, playing alongside [[England national cricket team|England]] cricketer [[Steven Davies]].<ref name=guardian/>
==Club career== ===Shrewsbury Town=== While still a 15-year-old schoolboy, Hart travelled with the [[first-team]] squad of his hometown club, [[Shrewsbury Town F.C.|Shrewsbury Town]], to [[Exeter City F.C.|Exeter City]] on 1 February 2003.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.11v11.com/matches/exeter-city-v-shrewsbury-town-01-february-2003-15331 |title=Exeter City v Shrewsbury Town, 01 February 2003 |work=11v11.com |publisher=AFS Enterprises |accessdate=29 May 2016 |date=1 February 2003}}</ref> He was a non-playing substitute on that occasion and fulfilled that role again versus [[Rochdale A.F.C.|Rochdale]] at [[Gay Meadow]] on 1 March 2003, still some six weeks short of his 16th birthday.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.11v11.com/matches/shrewsbury-town-v-rochdale-01-march-2003-15545 |title=Shrewsbury Town v Rochdale, 01 March 2003 |work=11v11.com |publisher=AFS Enterprises |date=1 March 2003 |accessdate=29 May 2016}}</ref> This match yielded Shrewsbury's final victory in a season that culminated in relegation to the [[Football Conference]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.shrewsburytown-mad.co.uk/results_fixtures/2002_2003/shrewsbury_town/index.shtml |title=Shrewsbury Town's results from season 2002/2003 |work=Shrewsbury Town Mad |accessdate=29 May 2016}}</ref> During the one season that Shrewsbury spent in the Conference, Hart made his senior debut on 20 April 2004, a day after his 17th birthday.<ref name=debut>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/14440757 |title=Goalkeeper Joe Hart signs new 5-year deal at Man City |publisher=BBC Sport |date=8 August 2011 |accessdate=12 May 2014}}</ref> He played the full 90 minutes in the match against [[Ebbsfleet United F.C.|Gravesend & Northfleet]].<ref name="Joe Hart debut">{{cite news |url=http://www.shropshirestar.com/sport/shrewsbury-town-fc/2016/04/20/on-this-day-joe-hart-debuts-for-shrewsbury-town/shrewsbury-town-v-gravesend-northfleet-20-4-04-debutant-goalkeeper-joe-hart |title=On this day: Joe Hart debuts at Shrewsbury |newspaper=Shropshire Star |date=20 April 2016 |accessdate=29 May 2016}}</ref> Four days later, he conceded three at [[Morecambe F.C.|Morecambe]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/morecambe-vs-shrewsbury/48559 |title=Morecambe 3–3 Shrewsbury Town |publisher=Sky Sports |accessdate=29 May 2016 |date=24 April 2004}}</ref>
Hart did not play again until April of the following year, as [[Scott Howie]] dominated goalkeeping duties. With Shrewsbury back in [[the Football League]] (the newly renamed [[EFL League Two|League Two]]) and struggling, Hart played six matches, conceding four goals.<ref name=Telegraph130111/>
From the start of the [[2005–06 in English football|2005–06 season]], Hart made the step up into the first team, and became the club's first-choice goalkeeper. He played a full 46-match league season, conceding 55 goals.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.espnfc.com/player/30462/joe-hart?season=2005 |title=Joe Hart |work=ESPN FC |accessdate=29 May 2016}}</ref> Despite conceding more than one goal per game, Hart won plaudits for his personal performances, winning his first England under-19 cap in October 2005, as a substitute against [[Poland national under-19 football team|Poland]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.keeperportal.co.uk/joe-hart-englands-number-1 |title=Joe Hart – England's Number 1 Goalkeeper |work=Keeper Portal |accessdate=29 May 2016 |date=17 June 2012}}</ref>
Hart also found admirers in the Premier League, with several top-flight scouts attending matches.<ref name=Telegraph130111>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/manchester-city/9792712/Manchester-City-and-England-in-safe-hands-with-Joe-Hart-between-the-posts.html |title=Manchester City and England in safe hands with Joe Hart between the posts |first=Mark |last=Bailey |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=11 January 2013 |accessdate=4 June 2016}}</ref> On 30 November 2005, the ''[[Shropshire Star]]'' newspaper reported that [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] goalkeeping coach [[Chris Woods]] had been present at Town's previous league match, a 4–3 loss at Rochdale.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nsno.co.uk/vintage/2005/12/02/everton-watch-young-keeper |title=Everton watch young Keeper |work=Nil Satis Nisi Optimum – Everton fans forum |accessdate=29 May 2016 |date=2 December 2005}}</ref> Manager [[Gary Peters (footballer)|Gary Peters]] said "Everton have been to watch him, but you could say the same about [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]], [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] and every other team in the [[Premier League|Premiership]]."<ref name="Hart 2010 World Cup">{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/england/players/6597577/Joe-Hart-England-goalkeeper-at-World-Cup-2010.html |title=Joe Hart: England goalkeeper at World Cup 2010 |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |accessdate=29 May 2016 |date=10 May 2010}}</ref> Speculation about his future continued for the duration of the season, and with the presence of their goalkeeping coach [[Tim Flowers]] at several matches, Manchester City became the most likely of his suitors.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/england/9317107/Euro-2012-England-goalkeeper-Joe-Hart-can-win-over-100-caps-insists-Tim-Flower-who-spotted-talent-early.html |title=Euro 2012: England goalkeeper Joe Hart can win over 100 caps insists Tim Flower who spotted talent early |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |accessdate=29 May 2016 |date=7 June 2012}}</ref>
Hart was announced as the top League Two player for January 2006 in the PFA Fans' Player of the Month Awards, voted for by fans via the [[Professional Footballers' Association]] website.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.givemefootball.com/display.cfm?article=7790&type=1 |title=PFA Fans' Player of the Month Awards for January 2006 |first=Dave |last=Smith |publisher=Professional Footballers' Association |date=7 February 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081205080459/http://www.givemefootball.com/pfa-awards/pfa-fans-player-of-the-month-awards-for-january-20 |archivedate=5 December 2008}}</ref> At the PFA Awards ceremony on 23 March 2006, it was announced that Hart had been voted as League Two's best goalkeeper for 2005–06 by his fellow professionals, earning him a place in the League Two [[PFA Team of the Year]].<ref name=PFA0506>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/4935884.stm |title=Gerrard named player of the year |publisher=BBC Sport |date=23 April 2006 |accessdate=15 December 2017}}</ref>
===Manchester City=== Hart's move to [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] was completed as soon as Hart returned from England under-19 duty in Belgium, where a defeat to [[Serbia national under-19 football team|Serbia and Montenegro]] in the [[UEFA U-19 Championship 2006 (Elite Round)|elite round]] meant England failed to qualify for the [[2006 UEFA European Under-19 Championship]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/england/archived/mens-u19s/news/2006/u19s_vserbiamontenegro |title=England fail to qualify |publisher=The Football Association |date=22 May 2006 |accessdate=4 May 2015}}</ref> It was reported at the time that City were to pay an initial £600,000 fee for Hart, rising to £1.5 million if undisclosed clauses were achieved,<ref>{{cite news |title=Goalkeeper Hart to join Man City |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/m/man_city/5006544.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=22 May 2006 |date=24 May 2006}}</ref> but John Wardle, then City chairman, revealed in 2012 that the transfer fee was actually £100,000.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Why Manchester City fans have former Blues chief to thank for the signing of hero Joe Hart |last=Spencer |first=Peter |url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/why-manchester-city-fans-have-former-blues-799798 |newspaper=Manchester Evening News |date=6 October 2012 |accessdate=4 May 2015}}</ref> Hart was recommended to City hierarchy by the club's goalkeeping coach Tim Flowers who believed he had great potential.<ref name="Joe Hart debut"/> Hart made his debut for City on 14 October 2006 after injuries ruled out [[Andreas Isaksson]] and [[Nicky Weaver]] for the [[Premier League]] match against [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]].<ref name="Hart Man City profile"/> He kept a [[Shutout|clean sheet]] in the match, which finished goalless.<ref>{{cite news |last=James |first=Stuart |title=Easy for Warnock to make point |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2006/oct/15/match.manchestercity |accessdate=12 August 2014 |newspaper=The Observer |location=London |date=15 October 2006}}</ref>
====2007: Loans to Tranmere Rovers and Blackpool==== Hart spent January 2007 on [[Loan (sports)|loan]] to [[EFL League One|League One]] club [[Tranmere Rovers F.C.|Tranmere Rovers]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/t/tranmere_rovers/6222679.stm |title=Tranmere sign City keeper on loan |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 January 2007 |accessdate=4 June 2016}}</ref> He made six appearances and conceded eight goals.<ref name=sb0607/> He was then named in his then club manager [[Stuart Pearce]]'s first squad in his part-time role as [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] coach, alongside another goalkeeper uncapped at U21 level, [[Ben Alnwick]]. He was not chosen to start the match on 6 February 2007 against [[Spain national under-21 football team|Spain]], but did come on as a substitute late in the match.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/internationals/6322149.stm |title=England U21 2–2 Spain U21 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=4 June 2016 |date=6 February 2007}}</ref>
In April 2007, Hart joined [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] on loan as cover for the injured trio of [[Rhys Evans]], [[Paul Rachubka]] and [[Lewis Edge]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/gossip_and_transfers/6596283.stm |title=Transfers – April 2007 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=4 June 2016 |date=26 April 2007}}</ref> He kept a clean sheet in a 2–0 win for Blackpool away to [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] on 9 April 2007, in his first appearance for ''the Seasiders''.<ref>{{cite news |title=Huddersfield 0–2 Blackpool |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/6513593.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=9 April 2007 |date=9 April 2007}}</ref> Blackpool won all five matches in which Hart appeared, including a 6–3 win away to [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] in his final appearance.<ref>{{cite news |title=Swansea 3–6 Blackpool |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_div_2/6603011.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=12 May 2007 |date=5 May 2007}}</ref>
====2007–09: First choice keeper at Manchester City==== [[File:Joehart.jpg|thumb|upright|Hart playing for [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] in 2008]]
On his return from a successful loan spell at Blackpool, then Manchester City manager [[Sven-Göran Eriksson]] named Hart as Manchester City's number one ahead of Andreas Isaksson.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/england/2287955/Joe-Harts-rise-gives-England-hope.html |title=Joe Hart's rise gives England hope |first=Henry |last=Winter |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |accessdate=4 June 2016 |date=4 January 2008}}</ref> After his performance against [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]], Eriksson named him as "one of the biggest talents in this country as a goalkeeper", and that he had the potential to become an England international in the future.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11679_3019958,00.html |title=Eriksson backing for Hart |first=Peter |last=Frazer |date=3 January 2008 |publisher=Sky Sports}}</ref> Only months later, he made his [[England national football team|England]] debut against [[Trinidad and Tobago national football team|Trinidad and Tobago]] on 1 June 2008.<ref name="Hart England debut">{{cite web |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/trin-tob-vs-england/103297 |title=Three and easy for England |first=Graeme |last=Bailey |publisher=Sky Sports |date=2 June 2008 |accessdate=27 June 2010}}</ref> In October, he was inducted to Shropshire Schools & Colleges Football Association's Hall of Fame along with former teammate [[David Edwards (footballer)|David Edwards]] in recognition of their achievements.<ref>{{cite news |title=Manchester City star Joe Hart in Shropshire hall of fame |url=http://www.shropshirestar.com/news/2008/10/23/joe-hart-in-county-hall-of-fame |newspaper=Shropshire Star |date=23 October 2008 |accessdate=4 May 2015}}</ref> Later that month, he signed a new five-year contract.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.shropshirestar.com/news/2008/10/27/hart-agrees-to-five-year-city-contract |title=Hart agrees to five-year City contract |newspaper=Shropshire Star |date=27 October 2008 |accessdate=4 May 2015}}</ref>
After Isaksson's departure to [[PSV Eindhoven]], Hart took the vacant number 1 jersey when the official squad numbers for the 2008–09 season were announced.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldfootball.net/teams/manchester-city/2009/2 |title=Manchester City " Squad 2008/2009 |publisher=WorldFootball.net |accessdate=4 June 2016}}</ref> However, his position as first-choice keeper was taken by [[Shay Given]] upon the Irishman's arrival at the club in January 2009.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/england/4593912/Englands-Fabio-Capello-still-keen-on-Joe-Hart.html |title=England's Fabio Capello still keen on Joe Hart |first=Henry |last=Winter |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=11 February 2009 |accessdate=4 June 2016}}</ref>
====2009–10: Loan to Birmingham City==== [[File:JoeHart Augsburg.jpg|thumb|upright|Hart with [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] in 2009]]
Having made no appearances for City since Given's arrival, rumours began to emerge of a loan move away from Manchester.{{citation needed|date=December 2018}} City secured the transfer of [[Stuart Taylor (footballer, born 1980)|Stuart Taylor]] from [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] on 23 June 2009, paving the way for Hart to leave.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2009/jun/23/manchester-city-stuart-taylor-aston-villa |title=Manchester City sign goalkeeper Stuart Taylor from Aston Villa |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=23 June 2009 |accessdate=4 June 2016}}</ref> The following day it was announced that Hart would spend the [[2009–10 Premier League]] season on loan to newly promoted [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Hart seals Birmingham loan move |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/m/man_city/8081307.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 June 2009 |accessdate=24 June 2009}}</ref> He made his debut in Birmingham's opening match of the season, a 1–0 defeat away to [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8197957.stm |title=Man Utd 1–0 Birmingham |first=Pranav |last=Soneji |publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 August 2009 |accessdate=1 February 2010}}</ref>
In the early part of the season, Hart made some errors which cost Birmingham City goals, and [[Maik Taylor]]'s clean sheet against Manchester City, a match for which Hart was ineligible, left manager [[Alex McLeish]] with a selection dilemma.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.birminghammail.net/birmingham-sport/birmingham-city-fc/birmingham-city-fc-news/2009/11/04/birmingham-city-maik-taylor-gives-alex-mcleish-a-selection-poser-97319-25088435/ |title=Maik Taylor gives Alex McLeish a selection poser |first=Andy |last=Walker |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |date=4 November 2009 |accessdate=1 February 2010}}</ref> McLeish chose Hart, who kept his place in the starting 11 as Birmingham went on a club-record 12-match unbeaten run in the top division<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11694_5850655,00.html |title=McLeish proud of Blues |publisher=Sky Sports |date=9 January 2010 |accessdate=28 February 2010}}</ref> and set a Premier League record by fielding the same starting 11 for nine consecutive matches.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/12037/5854263/the-cold-rush |title=The cold rush |publisher=Sky Sports |first=Martin |last=Tyler |date=12 January 2010 |accessdate=24 November 2015}}</ref> His performances improved:<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.birminghammail.net/birmingham-sport/birmingham-city-fc/birmingham-city-fc-news/2009/12/08/birmingham-city-keeper-tipped-by-boss-for-england-role-at-world-cup-97319-25345460/ |title=Birmingham City keeper tipped by boss for England role at World Cup |first=Colin |last=Tattum |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |date=8 December 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120930132757/http://www.birminghammail.net/birmingham-sport/birmingham-city-fc/birmingham-city-fc-news/2009/12/08/birmingham-city-keeper-tipped-by-boss-for-england-role-at-world-cup-97319-25345460/ |archivedate=30 September 2012}}</ref> against Chelsea in December, he "showed not only sharp judgment and reflexes, making three outstanding saves ... but a lack of fear also", despite needing staples in a gashed head sustained when diving at the feet of [[Salomon Kalou]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.birminghammail.net/birmingham-sport/birmingham-city-fc/birmingham-city-fc-match-reports/2009/12/28/birmingham-city-0-chelsea-0-colin-tattum-s-big-match-verdict-97319-25477621/ |title=Birmingham City 0, Chelsea 0: Colin Tattum's big match verdict |first=Colin |last=Tattum |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |date=28 December 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121015081552/http://www.birminghammail.net/birmingham-sport/birmingham-city-fc/birmingham-city-fc-match-reports/2009/12/28/birmingham-city-0-chelsea-0-colin-tattum-s-big-match-verdict-97319-25477621/2/ |archivedate=15 October 2012}}</ref> Hart was voted Birmingham City's Player of the Year for 2009–10,<ref name="Joe Scoops Top Award!">{{cite web |url=http://www.bcfc.com/page/News/NewsDetail/0,,10412~2048759,00.html |title=Joe Scoops Top Award! |publisher=Birmingham City F.C |date=10 May 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100514183744/http://www.bcfc.com/page/News/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10412~2048759%2C00.html |archivedate=14 May 2010 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> and nominated for the 2010 [[PFA Young Player of the Year]] award alongside [[Wayne Rooney]], [[Cesc Fàbregas]] and [[James Milner]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Man Utd striker Wayne Rooney shortlisted for PFA award |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8622316.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 April 2010 |accessdate=26 April 2010}}</ref> Though Milner won that award, Hart earned a place in the PFA Team of the Year.<ref name=PFA0910>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8643305.stm |title=Rooney is PFA player of the year |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 April 2010 |accessdate=15 December 2017}}</ref>
====2010–16: League and cup honours with Manchester City==== [[File:City defend-cropped.jpg|thumb|upright|Hart playing for Manchester City in 2011]]
After a successful spell at Birmingham, Hart earned a place in the England squad for the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]] in South Africa.<ref name="Hart 2010 World Cup"/> Manchester City manager [[Roberto Mancini]] was unsure over the future of Hart and dispatched his goalkeeping coach, [[Massimo Battara]] to watch over him during his loan spell at Birmingham City.<ref name=Battara/> Battara reported that Hart was a "very good goalkeeper, with very high physical and technical abilities" and advised that he kept Hart in his plans for the years ahead.<ref name=Battara>{{Cite news |title=Euro 2012: Italian influence made Hart grow fonder |url=http://www.thenational.ae/sport/football/euro-2012-italian-influence-made-hart-grow-fonder |first=Duncan |last=Castles |newspaper=The National |location=Abu Dhabi |date=15 June 2012 |accessdate=27 June 2012}}</ref> One of the major pre-season debates was whether Hart would start ahead of the experienced Shay Given after his return to City following an impressive loan spell with Birmingham City.<ref>{{cite news |title=Joe Hart will not stand for sitting on Manchester City bench |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2010/aug/01/joe-hart-shay-given-manchester-city |first=Louise |last=Taylor |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=1 August 2010 |accessdate=22 February 2018}}<br>{{cite news |title=Shay Given considers leaving Manchester City if he is second choice |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2010/aug/10/shay-given-manchester-city-joe-hart |first=Andy |last=Hunter |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=10 August 2010 |accessdate=22 February 2018}}</ref>
Hart was chosen ahead of Shay Given to start the opening match of the 2010–11 season against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]].<ref name=Sky100814/> He produced a [[man of the match]] performance, saving numerous challenging shots including a deflected effort from [[Benoît Assou-Ekotto]], which helped City to draw the match 0–0.<ref name=Sky100814>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/match_report/0,19764,11065_3285859,00.html |title=Hart keeps Spurs at bay |publisher=Sky Sports |date=14 August 2010 |accessdate=15 August 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100815002313/http://www.skysports.com/football/match_report/0%2C19764%2C11065_3285859%2C00.html |archivedate=15 August 2010 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> Hart also kept a clean sheet in Manchester City's 3–0 victory over [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], where he was still first-choice goalkeeper and made even more good saves, enhancing his reputation even further.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/8929542.stm |title=Man City 3–0 Liverpool |publisher=BBC Sport |first=Phil |last=McNulty |date=23 August 2010 |accessdate=4 June 2016}}</ref> Hart conceded his first goal of the season from a late penalty by [[Darren Bent]] in a 1–0 defeat at [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]], and made an error that led to [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]]' opening goal in a 1–1 draw two weeks later.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8948037.stm |title=Sunderland 1–0 Man City |first=Kevin |last=Darling |publisher=BBC Sport |date=29 August 2010 |accessdate=4 June 2016}}<br />{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/m/man_city/8994403.stm |title=Manchester City goalkeeper Joe Hart admits goal blunder |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 September 2010 |accessdate=4 June 2016}}</ref>
Hart helped his team overcome Manchester United in the FA Cup semi-final by producing an excellent early save to deny [[Dimitar Berbatov]] the opening goal; the match ended 1–0 to City, thanks to a goal scored by [[Yaya Touré]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/fa_cup/9457489.stm |title=Man City 1–0 Man Utd |first=Phil |last=McNulty |publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 April 2011 |accessdate=4 June 2016}}</ref> He kept another clean sheet against Tottenham Hotspur to earn his team a place in the [[UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] for the first time, and another in the [[2011 FA Cup Final|FA Cup final]] in which Manchester City beat [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] 1–0 with another goal from Touré.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/9480251.stm |title=Man City 1–0 Tottenham |first=Phil |last=McNulty |publisher=BBC Sport |date=10 May 2011 |accessdate=4 June 2016}}</ref><ref name=2011FAC>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/13346941 |title=Man City 1–0 Stoke |first=Phil |last=McNulty |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140525071238/https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/13346941 |archivedate=25 May 2014}}</ref>
[[File:Joe Hart and Kolo Toure cropped.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Hart and [[Kolo Touré]] celebrating winning the [[Premier League]] with Manchester City in 2012]]
Hart's 18 clean sheets in the [[2010–11 Premier League]] season earned him the [[Premier League Golden Glove]] award.<ref name=GGlove>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11095/10286338/petr-cech-wins-premier-league-golden-glove-award |title=Petr Cech wins Premier League Golden Glove award |first=Peter |last=Smith |publisher=Sky Sports |date=18 May 2016 |accessdate=4 June 2016}}</ref> He also set a new [[List of Manchester City F.C. records and statistics|club record]] for the most clean sheets during a season, with 29; the previous mark was set by Nicky Weaver with 26 when the team were playing [[1998–99 Football League Second Division|two divisions lower]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/manchester-city/8553757/Manchester-City-and-England-goalkeeper-Joe-Harts-show-stopping-story-of-success.html |title=Manchester City and England goalkeeper Joe Hart's show-stopping story of success |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=3 June 2011 |accessdate=4 June 2016}}</ref> He also received City's Performance of the Season award for the match against Tottenham Hotspur in August 2010.<ref name=MCFCAwards1011>{{cite web |url=http://www.mcfc.co.uk/News/Team-news/2011/May/Kompany-lands-Player-of-the-Year-double |title=Kompany lands Player of the Year double |first=Tim |last=Oscroft |publisher=Manchester City F.C. |date=23 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110526190503/http://www.mcfc.co.uk/News/Team-news/2011/May/Kompany-lands-Player-of-the-Year-double |archivedate=26 May 2011 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> Hart's position as City's "number one" was cemented when Given departed City for Aston Villa in July 2011.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/jul/18/shay-given-aston-villa |title=Shay Given signs for Aston Villa on a five-year deal |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=18 July 2011 |accessdate=25 August 2011}}</ref> On 8 August 2011, he signed a new contract until 2016.<ref name=debut/> Hart won the Golden Glove award for the second year running in 2011–12, and helped City to win their first Premier League title, and first top-flight title for 44 years, which they clinched on the final day of the season by beating [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] 3–2.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mcfc.co.uk/News/Team-news/2012/May/Hart-QPR-preview |title=Hart wins Golden Glove award |first=David |last=Clayton |publisher=Manchester City F.C. |date=11 May 2012 |accessdate=14 May 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120513051854/http://www.mcfc.co.uk/News/Team-news/2012/May/Hart-QPR-preview |archivedate=13 May 2012}}</ref><ref name=PL1112>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17973148 |title=Manchester City 3–2 QPR |first=Phil |last=McNulty |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 May 2012 |accessdate=14 May 2012}}</ref>
Hart's form dipped in the [[2012–13 Premier League]] season,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/mar/20/joe-hart-criticism-roberto-mancini |title=Joe Hart admits he is affected by criticism from Roberto Mancini |first=Jamie |last=Jackson |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=20 March 2013 |accessdate=4 June 2016}}</ref> although he still won the Golden Glove award for keeping most clean sheets<ref name=GGlove/> despite rivals Manchester United regaining their title as revenge for the previous season's [[2011–12 Premier League|last-day title win on goal difference]].<ref name=PL1112/><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/manchester-united/10011341/Manchester-Uniteds-Premier-League-title-triumph-was-fuelled-by-Alex-Fergusons-desire-to-get-revenge-on-City.html |title=Manchester United's Premier League title triumph was fuelled by Alex Ferguson's desire to get revenge on City |first=Paul |last=Hayward |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=22 April 2013 |accessdate=4 June 2016}}</ref> He started in goal for Manchester City in the [[2013 FA Cup Final]] against [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] but let in a 90th-minute header by [[Ben Watson (footballer, born July 1985)|Ben Watson]]; Wigan won 1–0, and City ended the season without winning a trophy.<ref name=2013FAC>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22409634 |title=Man City 0–1 Wigan |first=Phil |last=McNulty |publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 May 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160112212927/https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22409634 |archivedate=12 January 2016}}</ref> His form continued to dip in the [[2013–14 Premier League]] season and, following conceding a decisive 90th-minute goal by [[Fernando Torres]] in a 2–1 loss to Chelsea at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]] on 27 October, he was replaced by [[Costel Pantilimon]] for a home match against [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] which City won 7–0.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11096/8996818/say-it-aint-so-joe |title=Say it ain't so, Joe |first=Adam |last=Bate |publisher=Sky Sports |date=30 October 2013 |accessdate=4 June 2016}}<br />{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/22409634 |title=Chelsea 2–1 Manchester City |first=Phil |last=McNulty |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 October 2013 |accessdate=4 June 2016}}<br />{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24778956 |title=Joe Hart: Manchester City keeper dropped for the Norwich game on 3 November |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 November 2013 |accessdate=4 June 2016}}<br />{{cite news |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/manchester-city-7-norwich-0-costel-pantilimon-has-little-to-do-as-city-hit-seven-8919005.html |title=Manchester City 7 Norwich 0: Costel Pantilimon has little to do as City hit seven |newspaper=London Evening Standard |location=London |date=2 November 2013 |accessdate=4 June 2016}}</ref> A month later, Hart returned to the Manchester City team for a [[2013–14 UEFA Champions League group stage#Group D|Champions League group match]] against [[FC Viktoria Plzeň|Viktoria Plzeň]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/european/manchester-city-4-plzen-2-match-report-joe-hart-puts-in-errorfree-display-in-champions-league-game-vital-perhaps-only-for-him-8968204.html |title=Manchester City 4 Plzen 2 match report: Joe Hart puts in error-free display in Champions League game vital perhaps only for him |date=28 November 2013 |newspaper=The Independent |location=London |first=Tim |last=Rich |accessdate=4 May 2015}}</ref> Hart regained his place as City's starting goalkeeper in the Premier League in a 4–2 win over [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] on 21 December 2013,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/25377021 |title=Fulham 2–4 Manchester City |date=21 December 2013 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> and remained first choice as the team went on to win the league for the second time in three seasons.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/england/2014/may/joe-hart-james-milner-manchester-city-win-premier-league-title |title=Hart and Milner win Premier League with Manchester City |publisher=The Football Association |date=11 May 2015 |accessdate=4 June 2016}}</ref>
On 24 February 2015, Hart saved a penalty kick from five-time [[FIFA Ballon d'Or]] winner [[Lionel Messi]] in a [[2014–15 UEFA Champions League knockout stage|Champions League round of 16]] fixture against [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/live/football/30498332 |title=Man City 1–2 Barcelona – reaction |date=25 February 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=4 May 2015}}</ref> After the return leg of the same tie Messi described Hart as a "phenomenon" after a performance where he produced a record-breaking 10 saves during the match.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31956842 |title=Lionel Messi calls Joe Hart a 'phenomenon' after Barcelona win |publisher=BBC Sport |date=19 March 2015 |accessdate=4 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31922160 |title=Barcelona 1–0 Manchester City (agg 3–1) |first=Alistair |last=Magowan |publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 March 2015 |accessdate=4 May 2015}}</ref> Hart ended the [[2014–15 Premier League|2014–15 season]] by keeping a clean sheet against [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] in his 300th appearance for Manchester City to win the Premier League Golden Glove award for the fourth time.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mcfc.com/News/Team-news/2015/May/Joe-Hart-Golden-Glove-1178/1432488619 |title=Hart grabs Golden Glove award |publisher=Manchester City F.C. |date=24 May 2015 |accessdate=4 June 2016}}</ref>
As he had been in [[2014 Football League Cup Final|2014]],<ref name=2014LC>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/26311649 |title=Manchester City 3–1 Sunderland |first=Phil |last=McNulty |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2 March 2014 |accessdate=4 June 2016}}</ref> Hart was on the bench for the [[2016 Football League Cup Final|2016 League Cup Final]]; this time, his understudy [[Willy Caballero]] featured in a penalty shoot-out victory against Liverpool.<ref name=2016LC>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35624164 |title=Liverpool 1–1 Manchester City |first=Phil |last=McNulty |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 February 2016 |accessdate=15 December 2017}}</ref> On 6 April, Hart saved a penalty kick from [[Zlatan Ibrahimović]] in Manchester City's [[2015–16 UEFA Champions League knockout phase#Quarter-finals|Champions League quarter-final first leg]] against [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|Paris Saint-Germain]] at the [[Parc des Princes]].<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/live/2016/apr/06/psg-manchester-city-champions-league-live |title=PSG 2–2 Man City As it happened |first=Paul |last=Doyle |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=6 April 2016 |accessdate=4 June 2016}}</ref> It was his second penalty save of the season's competition, after previously keeping out [[Raffael (footballer)|Raffael]]'s kick in a 2–1 [[2015–16 UEFA Champions League group stage|group stage]] win at [[Borussia Mönchengladbach]] on 30 September 2015.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.espnfc.com.au/uefa-champions-league/story/2640958/pellegrini-joy-at-hart-penalty-save-in-man-city-gladbach-win |title=Pellegrini praises Joe Hart as penalty save helps Man City beat Gladbach |publisher=ESPN FC |date=30 September 2015 |accessdate=4 June 2016}}</ref>
====2016–17: Loan to Torino==== On 13 August 2016, Hart was dropped by new manager [[Pep Guardiola]] for the first match of the [[2016–17 Premier League]] season. The absence followed his poor performances at [[UEFA Euro 2016]],<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/joe-hart-dropped-pep-guardiola-8622254 |title=Joe Hart dropped by Pep Guardiola for Manchester City opener against Sunderland |last=Rathborn |first=Jack |newspaper=Daily Mirror |location=London |date=13 August 2016 |accessdate=14 August 2016}}</ref> and Guardiola's desire for a player with better footwork who could fill a [[sweeper-keeper]] role.<ref>{{cite web |title=Joe Hart: Man City goalkeeper can leave – Pep Guardiola |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37130356 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=30 August 2016}}</ref> Hart made his first start of the 2016–17 season in a [[2016-17 UEFA Champions League|Champions League qualifying]] match against [[FC Steaua București|Steaua Bucharest]], as [[captain (association football)|captain]] of the City side that won 1–0 on the night, 6–0 on aggregate.<ref>{{cite news |title=Manchester City 1–0 (agg: 6–0) Steaua Bucharest |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37158791 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 August 2016 |accessdate=25 August 2016 |first=Neil |last=Johnston}}</ref> Following the match, Hart was applauded by the crowd, in an atmosphere which was described as resembling a pre-departure testimonial.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Bascombe |first1=Chris |title=Man City 1 Steaua Bucharest 0 (agg 6–0), Joe Hart leads City through to Champions League group stage on emotional night for 'No 1' |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/08/24/manchester-city-vs-steaua-bucharest-champions-league-live/ |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |accessdate=30 August 2016}}</ref> Following speculation linking Hart with various top European clubs, including Arsenal, [[Borussia Dortmund]], Everton, Liverpool, [[A.C. Milan|Milan]] and [[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]], Hart surprisingly decided to pursue a season-long loan in the [[Serie A]] with [[Torino F.C.|Torino]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Hart joins Torino on season-long loan deal – agent |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-soccer-england-mci-hart-idUKKCN115157 |agency=Reuters |accessdate=30 August 2016}}</ref> In doing so, he became the first English goalkeeper to sign for a Serie A club since the league's inception in 1929.<ref>{{cite web |last=Bate |first=Adam |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11855/10558111/joe-hart-to-torino-british-players-in-serie-a-share-their-memories-of-italy |title=Joe Hart to Torino: British players in Serie A share their memories of Italy |publisher=[[Sky Sports]] |accessdate=6 July 2017}}</ref>
On 11 September 2016, Hart suffered a tough start in his debut for Torino, being partly at fault for the equaliser in a 2–1 away defeat to [[Atalanta B.C.|Atalanta]] when his punch from a corner fell at the feet of an opposing attacker who scored.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/live/football/37268939 |title=Joe Hart loses on Torino debut |date=11 September 2016 |publisher=BBC Sports}}</ref> However, Hart then kept consecutive clean sheets in his next two appearances against Empoli and Pescara, both of which ended 0–0.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://it.eurosport.com/calcio/serie-a/2016-2017/le-pagelle-di-torino-empoli-0-0_sto5858434/story.shtml |title=Le pagelle di Torino-Empoli 0–0 |date=18 September 2016 |accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gazzetta.it/Calcio/Serie-A/Pescara/21-09-2016/pescara-torino-0-0-squadra-oddo-non-riesce-sfruttare-doppia-superiorita-numerica-170139786153.shtml |title=Pescara-Torino 0–0: Acquah e Vives espulsi |accessdate=22 September 2016}}</ref> Hart played in all 36 of Torino's remaining league matches in the 2016–17 season,<ref>{{soccerbase season|34502|2016|accessdate=18 July 2017}}</ref> but in April the club's president Urbano Cairo suggested his level of performance had dropped amid transfer speculation.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/european/joe-hart-manchester-city-to-torino-mistakes-chairman-a7687006.html |title=Angry Torino chairman says Joe Hart's 'performance levels have dropped' because of increased transfer speculation |date=17 April 2017 |newspaper=The Independent|access-date=4 September 2017}}</ref>
The club finished in ninth position (of 20) in Serie A, conceding 66 goals in 38 matches, the fourth-highest number in the league.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.skysports.com/serie-a-table/2016 |title=Final Table Serie A 2016–17 |publisher=Sky Sports |archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=5 September 2017}}</ref>
====2017–18: Loan to West Ham United==== On 18 July 2017, Hart signed for Premier League club [[West Ham United]] on a season-long loan, having been permitted to find another club by City.<ref>{{cite news |first=Simon |last=Stone |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40625646 |title=Joe Hart: Manchester City keeper joins West Ham on loan |publisher=''BBC Sport'' |date=18 July 2017 |accessdate=18 July 2017}}</ref> He made his debut for West Ham on 13 August 2017, in a 4–0 defeat away to Manchester United and conceded 10 goals in his first three appearances, although West Ham captain [[Mark Noble]] defended his goalkeeper's performances.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11685/11017009/joe-hart-not-to-blame-for-west-hams-start-says-mark-noble |title=Joe Hart not to blame for West Ham's start, says Mark Noble |publisher=''Sky Sports''|access-date=4 September 2017}}</ref> In a ''[[Daily Telegraph]]'' article, it was claimed that opposing forwards were able to exploit a "weakness" against "low shots to his left."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2017/09/08/revealed-joe-hart-has-one-significant-weak-spot-opposition-players/ |title=Revealed: Joe Hart has one significant weak spot and opposition players are starting to notice |first=Alistair |last=Tweedale |newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=8 September 2017 |accessdate=14 September 2017}}</ref>
=== Burnley === On 7 August 2018, [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] announced the signing of Hart from Manchester City on an initial two-year contract for an undisclosed fee, believed to be in the region of £3.5m.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/news/2018/august/home-is-where-the-hart-is/ |title=Home Is Where The Hart Is As Joe Signs In |publisher=Burnley F.C. |date=7 August 2018 |accessdate=8 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Joe Hart: Burnley sign keeper for about £3.5m from Manchester City on two-year deal |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 August 2018 |accessdate=8 August 2018 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45083130}}</ref> He made his Burnley debut on 9 August in the first leg of the third qualifying round of the [[Europa League]] against [[İstanbul Başakşehir F.K.|İstanbul Başakşehir]] keeping a clean sheet in a 0–0 draw.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45083327 |title=Istanbul Basaksehir 0–0 Burnley |date=9 August 2018 |publisher= BBC Sport}}</ref>
==International career== ===Youth levels=== Hart made his first international appearance in September 2005 in an [[England national under-19 football team|England under-19]] friendly match against [[Belgium national under-19 football team|Belgium]] at [[The Darlington Arena|Darlington]]; replacing starting goalkeeper Ben Alnwick at half-time, he was unable to save the penalty that made the score 3–2, but with three minutes left made a "terrific one on one save" from an unmarked attacker.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.darlington-fc.net.p.preprod.performgroup.com/page/NewsDetail/0,,10339~709746,00.html |title=England under 19's claim 3–2 win over Belgium |first=Garry |last=Mann |publisher=Darlington F.C. |date=7 September 2005 |accessdate=4 June 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160625035212/http://www.darlington-fc.net.p.preprod.performgroup.com/page/NewsDetail/0,,10339~709746,00.html |archivedate=25 June 2016}}</ref><ref name=EFO19/> He played in five more matches for the under-19s, his last a 1–0 defeat away to Serbia and Montenegro on 22 May 2006.<ref name=EFO19>{{cite web |url=http://www.englandfootballonline.com/MatchRsl/MatchRslTmU19pg1.html |title=England's matches: The under-19s 1991–2010 |work=England Football Online |publisher=Chris Goodwin, Glen Isherwood & Peter Young |date=27 August 2014 |accessdate=22 September 2017}}</ref><ref name=FAProfile>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/england/all-teams/players/h/joe-hart |title=Joe Hart |publisher=The Football Association |accessdate=4 June 2016}}</ref>
After making his under-21 debut as a substitute for [[Scott Carson]] in a 2–2 draw with Spain,<ref name=FAProfile/> Hart was selected by Stuart Pearce in the preliminary England Under-21 30-man squad for the [[2007 UEFA European Under-21 Championship]], and made the final 23.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/internationals/6644497.stm |title=FA names 30-man England U21 squad |publisher=BBC Sport |date=10 May 2007 |accessdate=4 June 2016}}<br />{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/internationals/6702087.stm |title=Bentley picked for England U21s |publisher=BBC Sport |date=30 May 2007 |accessdate=4 June 2016}}</ref> In the team's final friendly before the finals, Hart was selected for his first under-21 start, and played the full 90 minutes in a 5–0 win over [[Slovakia national under-21 football team|Slovakia]] at [[Carrow Road]].<ref name=EFO21>{{cite web |url=http://www.englandfootballonline.com/MatchRsl/MatchRslTmU21pg3.html |title=England's matches: The under-21s 2001–2010 |work=England Football Online |publisher=Chris Goodwin, Glen Isherwood & Peter Young |date=23 February 2014 |accessdate=22 September 2017}}</ref> However, Hart took no part in the finals, with Carson playing in all four of England's fixtures.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.uefa.com/under21/season=2007/teams/team=200039/squad/index.html |title=2006/07 UEFA European Under-21 Championship: England under-21 squad |publisher=UEFA |date=20 March 2013 |accessdate=4 June 2016}}</ref>
Hart played in all the qualifying matches for the [[2009 UEFA European Under-21 Championship|2009 European Championships]],<ref name=EFO21/> In the finals, he started the first two group-stage matches and was rested for the last match as England had already sealed their passage to the knock-out stage.<ref name=U21Appeal/> In the semi-final against [[Sweden national under-21 football team|Sweden]], he conceded three goals in the second half as the match ended 3–3 [[after extra time]], but made up for it by saving a penalty and scoring another as England won 5–4 in the [[penalty shoot-out (association football)|shoot-out]].<ref name=U21Semi/> However, he was yellow-carded for leaving his line to talk to [[Mikael Lustig]] as he prepared to take his penalty.<ref name=U21Semi>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2009/jun/26/england-sweden-under21 |title=Joe Hart heroics earn final place after Sweden fight back |first=David |last=Hytner |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=26 June 2009 |accessdate=4 June 2016}}</ref> England's appeal was rejected, so Hart was suspended for the final;<ref name=U21Appeal>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/england/5675894/England-keeper-Joe-Hart-will-miss-European-U21-Championship-final-after-appeal-rejected.html |title=England keeper Joe Hart will miss European U21 Championship final after appeal rejected |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=28 June 2009 |accessdate=4 June 2016}}</ref> [[Scott Loach]] kept goal as England lost 4–0 to [[Germany national under-21 football team|Germany]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.uefa.com/under21/season=2009/matches/round=15089/match=2001198/postmatch/report/index.html |title=Germany claim first Under-21 crown |first=Michael |last=Harrold |publisher=UEFA |date=30 June 2009 |accessdate=4 June 2016}}</ref>
===Senior team=== [[File:Joe Hart 2012.JPG|thumb|upright|Hart playing for [[England national football team|England]] at [[UEFA Euro 2012]]]]
Having been a regular in the England under-21 squad, Hart was called up by [[Fabio Capello]] to the senior England team for the friendly matches against the [[United States men's national soccer team|United States]] and Trinidad and Tobago. An unused substitute against the United States, he made his debut against Trinidad and Tobago on 1 June 2008 at the [[Hasely Crawford Stadium]], [[Port of Spain]]. He came on at half time for [[David James (footballer, born 1970)|David James]] with England 2–0 up, eventually running out 3–0 winners.<ref name="Hart England debut"/> However, Hart's senior England debut did not earn Shrewsbury Town the expected bonus of £500,000 from Manchester City, as negotiated as part of his transfer in 2006, because it was not a competitive match.<ref>{{cite web |title=Town in Wait For Extra Hart Money |newspaper=Shropshire Star |url=http://www.shropshirestar.com/news/2008/07/01/town-in-wait-for-extra-hart-money/ |date=1 July 2008 |accessdate=4 May 2015}}</ref>
Hart kept his place in the squad for a friendly against the [[Czech Republic national football team|Czech Republic]] in August, but remained unused.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2008/aug/17/englandfootballteam |title=Capello names Heskey in favour of Young, Crouch and Bent |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=17 August 2008 |accessdate=4 June 2016}}</ref> After Blackburn Rovers goalkeeper [[Paul Robinson (footballer, born 1979)|Paul Robinson]] withdrew from the squad for [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification – UEFA Group 6|World Cup qualifiers]] against [[Ukraine national football team|Ukraine]] and [[Belarus national football team|Belarus]] in October 2009, Hart took his place,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/international/hart-and-cahill-receive-england-call-1798499.html |title=Hart and Cahill receive England call |newspaper=The Independent |location=London |date=6 October 2009 |accessdate=4 June 2016}}</ref> and in November, he was called up for a friendly against [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]],<ref>{{cite news |title=Darren Bent called up to England squad for friendly against Brazil |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2009/nov/08/darren-bent-england-brazil |newspaper=The Guardian |date=8 November 2009 |location=London |accessdate=6 May 2010}}</ref> but he did not appear in either match.<ref name=englandstats>{{cite web |url=http://englandstats.com/players.php?pid=1156 |title=Charles Joseph Hart |work=Englandstats.com |publisher=Davey Naylor |accessdate=4 June 2016}}</ref>
Capello named Hart in his provisional 30-man squad for the 2010 FIFA World Cup.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/world_cup_2010/8673706.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Fabio Capello makes surprise England World Cup choices |date=11 May 2010 |accessdate=1 June 2010}}</ref> Hart played the second half of both of England's warm-up matches, replacing [[Robert Green]] against [[Mexico national football team|Mexico]] and James against [[Japan national football team|Japan]], and kept a clean sheet in each case.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/world_cup_2010/8699042.stm |first=Phil |last=McNulty |publisher=BBC Sport |title=England 3–1 Mexico |date=24 May 2010 |accessdate=1 June 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/world_cup_2010/8712673.stm |first=Marc |last=Vesty |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Japan 1–2 England |date=30 May 2010 |accessdate=1 June 2010}}</ref> All three goalkeepers, Hart, Green and James, were included in the final 23-man selection.<ref>{{cite news |title=Theo Walcott left out of England squad |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/world_cup_2010/8713742.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 June 2010 |accessdate=1 June 2010}}</ref>
Hart did not feature in the World Cup but started England's next match, a friendly against [[Hungary national football team|Hungary]], to earn his fourth cap.<ref name=englandstats/> He conceded his first England goal in dubious circumstances when the ball appeared not to have crossed the line from a deflection from [[Phil Jagielka]], and made a vital late save from [[Zoltán Gera]] as England won 2–1.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/8902576.stm |title=England 2–1 Hungary |first=Paul |last=Gerrard |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2 September 2010 |accessdate=4 June 2016}}</ref> Hart was given his first competitive cap in a UEFA Euro 2012 qualifier, a 4–0 win against Bulgaria at [[Wembley Stadium]]; he made three crucial saves, one of which he palmed away to begin the counterattack that led to an England goal.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.fourfourtwo.com/news/defoe-hat-trick-helps-batter-bulgaria |title=Defoe hat-trick helps batter Bulgaria |magazine=FourFourTwo |date=3 September 2010 |accessdate=4 June 2016}}</ref> He won another two caps November 2011 in friendlies against world champions [[Spain national football team|Spain]] and [[Sweden national football team|Sweden]], in each case keeping a clean sheet in a 1–0 England victory.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/15693231.stm |title=International friendly: England 1–0 Spain |first=Phil |last=McNulty |publisher=BBC Sport |date=12 November 2011 |accessdate=4 June 2016}}<br />{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/15709627.stm |title=International friendly: England 1–0 Sweden |first=Phil |last=McNulty |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 November 2011 |accessdate=4 June 2016}}</ref>
In February 2012, after the position was stripped from [[John Terry]], some players<ref>{{cite news |title=James Milner backs 'unbelievable' Joe Hart for England captaincy |url=https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/james-milner-backs-unbelievable-joe-681796 |newspaper=Manchester Evening News |date=13 February 2012 |accessdate=22 February 2018}}</ref> and pundits<ref>{{Cite news |title=Joe Hart could lead England after Steven Gerrard short-term fix |last=White |first=Duncan |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/england/9061632/Joe-Hart-could-lead-England-after-Steven-Gerrard-short-term-fix.html |date=4 February 2012 |accessdate=19 February 2012 |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London}}</ref> backed Hart for England captaincy citing his strong performances and positive image.
[[File:Gol Suarez!! - Luis was on a weelchair 28 days before this game! - 140619-6442-jikatu (14319448420).jpg|thumb|left|upright|Hart (right) playing for England at the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]]]]
On 16 May 2012, new England manager [[Roy Hodgson]] named Hart in his [[UEFA Euro 2012]] squad.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18081125 |title=England Euro 2012 squad – Ruddy, Carroll & Defoe in, Ferdinand out |publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 May 2012 |accessdate=4 June 2012}}</ref> He played in England's second warm-up friendly, against [[Belgium national football team|Belgium]] at Wembley Stadium, keeping a clean sheet as England won 1–0.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18294160 |title=England 1–0 Belgium |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2 June 2012 |accessdate=4 June 2012}}</ref> In the tournament he made the most saves of any goalkeeper in the group phase with 14.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Euro 2012: Joe Hart justifies hype to lead England's renaissance |last=Fifield |first=Dominic |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2012/jun/21/euro-2012-joe-hart-england-renaissance |newspaper=The Guardian |date=21 June 2012 |accessdate=27 June 2012 |location=London}}</ref> However, he was beaten by [[Andrea Pirlo]]'s "[[Panenka (penalty kick)|panenka]]" shot in England's penalty shoot-out defeat to Italy in the quarter-finals. Pirlo had stated that Hart's antics led to him thinking that "he had to get off his high horse".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.goal.com/en-us/news/3396/euro-2012/2012/06/26/3202186/pirlo-germany-are-afraid-of-italy |title=Pirlo: Germany is afraid of Italy |publisher=Goal.com |date=26 June 2012 |accessdate=12 May 2014}}</ref>
On 6 February 2013, Hart saved a penalty kick and the subsequent follow-up shot from [[Ronaldinho]] in a friendly match against Brazil at Wembley Stadium. This double save proved to be crucial in helping England win the match 2–1, and thereby securing their first win over Brazil for 23 years.<ref>{{Cite news |title=England 2–1 Brazil |last=McNulty |first=Phil |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21317048 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 March 2013 |accessdate=21 March 2013}}</ref>
[[File:Uruguay and England match at the FIFA World Cup 2014-06-19 - jikatu (14307138939).jpg|thumb|250px|Hart, behind England captain [[Steven Gerrard]], shaking hands with Uruguay's [[Edinson Cavani]] at the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]], 19 June 2014.]]
Hart was selected for his second [[2014 FIFA World Cup|FIFA World Cup in 2014]].<ref>{{cite news |title=World Cup 2014: England name Ross Barkley in squad |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27362447 |accessdate=12 August 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=12 May 2014}}</ref> He made his tournament debut in England's first group match, a 2–1 defeat to Italy in [[Manaus]],<ref>{{cite news |last=McNulty |first=Phil |title=England 1–2 Italy |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25285071 |accessdate=12 August 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 June 2014}}</ref> and also played in the next match, a loss by the same scoreline to [[Uruguay national football team|Uruguay]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=McNulty |first1=Phil |title=Uruguay 2–1 England |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25285176 |accessdate=12 August 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=19 June 2014}}</ref> With England not likely to advance, Hodgson made changes for their last match, against [[Costa Rica national football team|Costa Rica]], with [[Ben Foster (footballer)|Ben Foster]] playing in goal instead.<ref>{{cite news |last1=McNulty |first1=Phil |title=Costa Rica 0–0 England |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25285354 |accessdate=12 August 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 June 2014}}</ref>

Hart was included in England's 23-man squad for UEFA Euro 2016.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuro-finals/season=2016/teams/team=39/squad/index.html |title=England: Squad: Final tournament |publisher=UEFA |accessdate=6 June 2016}}</ref> In the second match, against [[Wales national football team|Wales]] in [[Lens, Pas-de-Calais|Lens]], he made an error to allow [[Gareth Bale]] to score from a long-range free kick, although England came back to win 2–1.<ref>{{cite news |last1=De Menezes |first1=Jack |title=England vs Wales Euro 2016: Joe Hart blunder infuriates English fans on Twitter after Gareth Bale goal |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/international/england-vs-wales-euro-2016-joe-hart-error-infuriates-english-fans-twitter-gareth-bale-goal-a7085721.html |accessdate=27 June 2016 |newspaper=The Independent |location=London |date=16 June 2016}}</ref> Hart made another mistake to let in a winning goal from [[Kolbeinn Sigþórsson]] in the defeat to [[Iceland national football team|Iceland]] in the last 16, after which he admitted that criticism of the team would be justifiable.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Daly |first1=Jim |title=England goalkeeper Joe Hart takes blame for his performance vs Iceland and claims team deserve criticism |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/england-goalkeeper-joe-hart-takes-8298448 |accessdate=28 June 2016 |newspaper=Daily Mirror |location=London |date=27 June 2016}}</ref>
